title: CTRL0000071086 - Transcribed Interview of Austin Boedigheimer, (April 20, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
INTERVIEW OF:
AUSTIN BOEDIGHEIMER
Wednesday, April 20, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held 5480 O'Neill HOB, commencing at
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
CHIEF CLERK
SENIOR INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
INVESTIGATOR
INVESTIGATOR
INVESTIGATOR
For AUSTIN BOEDIGHEIMER:
TODD STEGGERDA
This is a transcribed interview of Austin Boedigheimer
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate The January 6th attack on the
U.S. Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503. At this time, I'd ask the witness to please
state your full name and spell your last name for the record.
Mr. Boedigheimer.
Austin Boedigheimer. That's B-o-e-d-i-g-h-e-i-m-e-r.
This will be a staff lead interview. The members may
choose to ask questions. I will note that there are no members currently present in the
interview. My name is
the Select Committee.
and I am an investigative counsel with
With me, from the Select Committee staff are
senior investigative
investigator; and joined on the Webex we have
who are both investigators. At this time, I ask counsel to
identify themselves for the record, please.
Mr. Steggerda.
My name is Todd Steggerda, S-t-e-g-g-e-r-d-a. I'm a partner at
McGuireWoods in Washington. I'm joined by my colleague and associate at
McGuireWoods, Emily Kelley, K-e-1-1-e-y, and we are counsel for Mr. Boedingheimer in his
individual capacity.
All right Mr. Boedingheimer, you are voluntarily here for
this transcribed interview. Some ground rules for the interview. There's an official
recorder transcribing the record of this interview. The reporter's transcription is the
official record of the proceeding.
The proceeding is also audio and video recorded. Please wait until each question is
completed before you begin to respond. We will do our best to wait until your response is
complete before we ask the next question. The reporter cannot note non-verbal
responses such as shaking or nodding your head. So, it is important that you respond to
each question with an audible verbal response.
Please give complete answers to the best of your recollection. If a question is
unclear, please ask for clarification. If you do not know what the answer, please just say
so. I remind you that it is unlawful to purposely provide untruthful testimony to
Congressional investigators.
Logistically, any time you want to break or want to discuss anything with your
lawyers we're happy to accommodate so, please just let us know. Do you have any
questions before we get started?
Mr. Boedigheimer.
Okay.
No. No questions.
Mr. Steggerda.
And if I could just put on the record a request for a copy of the
video recording and the transcript when it's done. I know you probably can't honor that
request at the moment, but I'd like to have it in the record.
EXAMINATION
BY
Q
Now, Mr. Boedingheimer, do you recall that we met, I believe, late last year
for an informal interview?
A
Yeah. I remember meeting.
Q
All right. So, today's interview will be very similar to that interview, many of
the same topics and questions. Can you provide us with your date of birth please?
A
Q
And where do you reside?
A
I live in
Q
And what's your cell phone number?
A
Q
Was that the cell phone number you had in December 2020 and January '21?
A
Yes. Same cell phone. Yeah.
Q
And what e-mail addresses did you use December 2020 and January '21?
A
I used my GOP e-mail address which would have been
aboedigheimer@gop.com as well as my personal e-mail which is
Q
Any other e-mail addresses?
A
I have access, I do have other e-mail but wasn't using them.
Q
What about social media? What social media did you have around that same
period? What were those handles?
A
I have a Face book and a Twitter. I'm not sure what my twitter handle is. I
can't remember what it is.
Q
Okay. At that time did you actively use it?
A
Use it mostly to look at tweets more than to post myself. I think it's -- I don't
Q
I'm sorry. You use it mostly to look at tweets.
A
Yeah.
Q
Okay. We'll ask your counsel to provide the handle. What's your educational
know.
background?
A
I have a Bachelors from Saint Martin's University.
Q
In what area?
A
It's in Interdisciplinary Studies with Business and English.
Q
Let's do a quick background on your professional background. Let's start
with your work for in 2016 with the Trump Make America Great Again Committee.
A
In 2016 I was an RNC employee. I was working as an e-mail marketing
coordinator. I was also at that time working for the Trump Make America Great Again
Committee.
Q
And tell us a bit more about your responsibilities at that time.
A
I created the HTML for fundraising e-mails, get out the vote e-mails and
really any other e-mails that were sent on the JFC or the RNC's behalf. And sent those out.
And that was the core of my responsibilities during that time.
Q
report delivered to the Trump for President Campaign?
And is it right you also were responsible for daily fundraising and analytic
A
Yeah. I was responsible for reports that I would share with my director at the
Q
Okay. And you created, executed daily e-mail analytics report including all
time.
engagements to six as well as conversion, revenue and ROl's. That also accurate?
A
I don't know if all those exact matrix are on the reports. But yeah, I created
reports for my director with many of those on there.
Q
I'm reading from Linkedln so, you tell me when you put your work history in
your Linkedln did you believe it to be accurate at that time?
A
Yes. When I put it in, I believed it to be accurate.
Q
All right. Is it fair that what I just read from your Linked In is what you did in
2016 for we'll call it TMAGAC?
A
Yeah. I think it's a fair summary of what I did.
Q
So, going to your next role you then, you continued to work for the RNC,
correct? In 2017?
A
Correct.
Q
And I have you there as, in 2017, you were an e-mail marketing director from
February '17 to April 2018. Is that accurate?
A
That sounds accurate.
Q
Okay. And then it says in May of 2018 you became director of innovative
marketing. What does that mean?
A
That was a title that I got from, kind of from a promotion from my boss. It
really still heavily focused on e-mail marketing, but I was getting into some text message
marketing as well. And just kind of helping out overall with marketing in digital.
Q
And when you say marketing is that another way of saying fundraising
through e-mails and text?
A
I would say it's digital marketing. So, it was primarily fund raising but we did
do other get out to vote efforts, volunteer efforts, things like that.
Q
Is it fair to say through e-mail and text trying to engage people and persuade
them to take an action. Is that fair?
A
Most of our e-mails would be like that. Some of them, there weren't actions
asked for but most of them, yeah.
Okay. And then you became deputy digital director in January in 2019. Is that
Q
correct?
A
That sounds correct.
Q
And then in October 2019 you became digital director. Is that accurate?
A
Sounds correct. Yeah.
Q
Okay. So, your Linked In indicates that when you became deputy digital
director you were in charge of on line fundraising for the RNC. Is that accurate?
A
Yeah. I was in charge of the fundraising team at least for on line fundraising.
Q
So is that, is it fair to say that becoming deputy digital director and digital
director was an expanse of your responsibilities?
A
Yeah is was elevated roles from before.
Q
So, can you give us a bit of background on what the new parameters of your
role were?
A
Yeah. From the earlier roles that we spoke about it was kind of executing the
e-mail marketing and then expanding it to doing e-mail marketing and text message
marketing. And then when we got to the roles that you just spoke about it was managing
the teams that were doing that.
So, yeah, an e-mail team, text message team and a copywriting team. And so, they
reported to me. So, that's kind of what the difference in the role was, kind of from
executing a more manager role.
Q
And when you were executing were you drafting copy yourself?
A
I did not often draft copy. I had to draft copy some, but it was never my
primary responsibility.
Q
Has that ever been your primary responsibility at any job?
A
No, I've never had a primary responsibility of being a copy writer.
Q
Okay. So, let's jump forward to 2020. We're in the middle of the presidential
campaign. Is it fair to say that your physical work location, assuming you weren't working
remotely, was the building that is referred to as the Annex?
A
Yeah. I worked primarily out of the office at Rosslyn.
Q
Okay. And that's what we call the Annex. Right?
A
Yeah. People call it that.
Q
And you were on the fifth floor. Is that correct?
A
At that time, I believe I was primarily on the fifth floor. There was a period
before that where I was on the 14th for a short period of time.
Q
So, let's jump forward to the middle of 2020, the summer.
A
Okay.
Q
And let's talk about the reporting structure of what we'll call the digital
team. So, what -- can you walk us through how the RNC versus the campaign made up a
digital team and how you fit in the reporting structure.
A
So, when we had moved, or I guess during this time period, we came
together to work collaboratively on the JFC, Joint Fundraising Committee for Trump Make
America Great Again.
Q
And, sorry to interrupt, but anytime you say we or they to us, it's helpful if
you say who you're talking about so the record can be clear.
A
Understood. Yeah. So, we, as in the RNC digital employees and then
campaign employees and vendors as well, came to work together on the JFC. And the
general structure was all working together on that goal. I was in charge of the on line
fundraising piece, which was primarily house file e-mail or e-mail marketing in general
and text message marketing.
Kevin was the lead of the RNC digital but also very senior in this kind of JFC digital
team. And then Gary Colby would have been the kind of the lead of the entire digital
team for the Joint Fundraising Committee. So, that's kind of where I fell in the structure.
There were other teams.
We had a reporting team, a lead there. Advertising, we had a lead for that team as
well. And graphic design and maybe a few others I'm not thinking of right now. But that
was generally what the structure was.
Q
And when you say Kevin, you mean Kevin Zambrano, Z-a-m-b-r-a-n-o?
A
Yeah. That's who I mean.
Q
And so, and his title was Chief Digital Officer?
A
Yeah.
Q
Is it fair to say you reported both to Kevin Zambrano and to Gary Colby?
A
I think that's fair to say. I think my direct report was Kevin but then we also
viewed Gary as a leader of kind of the digital JFC team.
Q
All right. And then, tell us a bit about Hannah Allred [ph].
A
Hannah, she was, I don't remember what her exact title was but she was one
of the copywriters on the team. She led a team of other copywriters and she reported to
me.
Q
Does it sound correct that her title was Chief Copywriter?
A
That sounds correct.
Q
Okay. And in the middle of 2020 is it fair to say that there were three
copywriters that reported to Hannah?
A
That sounds about right.
Q
You recall who they were?
A
2020. Alex Merglin would have been one. Alex Blinkhoff would have been
another. And I think at the time Ethan Katz as well. Those are the only three I can think of
right now.
Q
Now when we talk about you leading the e-mail fundraising team, is that fair
to say that's made up of fundraising e-mails and fundraising texts?
A
Yeah. There's a text demand in e-mail team but, yeah, I led both of those.
Q
Okay. And texting includes both the house file did you call it, which is that's
when the campaign sends out blast texts that people opted into, correct?
A
Yeah. When they send text from a, the short code that the campaign or
whoever it was had.
Q
the other bucket?
And there's the not opted texting, pure texting that Open Sesame ran. Is that
A
Yeah. Open Sesame did the Peer-to-Peer texting.
Q
Okay. Now as far as TMAGAC, T-M-A-G-A-C, tell us a bit about how, what
TMAGAC was and how that fit into the work you did as far as fund raising.
A
So, TMAGAC for my understanding of how it was, it was a joint fundraising
committee between the RNC, the Republican National Committee and Donald J. Trump
for president's campaign, or whatever the actual organization was called. So, the Joint
Fundraising Committee that we did our on line fundraising towards.
Q
So is it fair to say that virtually all the money that you helped raised in 2020
came through, initially TMAGAC?
A
TMAGAC.
Q
For our on line efforts I think the majority of it would have gone through
All right. So, let's, what I want to do next is talk a bit about the copywrite
process in broad terms and then we'll jump forward to the post-election period and
unpack the fundraising e-mails and things that happened at that time. So, tell us a bit
about how you trained new copywriters on the job in 2020. Well, I mean expand how you
train copywriters generally.
A
As when we train copywriters, generally, it would come in and we would, we
as in Hannah and myself in this instance, would walk them through previous copy that we
had done. We'd look at, you know, copy that had succeeded or raised money in the past.
And then gave them kind of the resources of where we could get ideas from whether it's
surrogates.
Prior to working with President Trump, we would have gave them say look at
Ronna's Twitter, Chairman Ron McDaniel. Then President Trump, of course, it was look at
his Twitter and his statements and kind of all those resources to help craft messages.
And then we had Com ms Alerts from the Com ms Team whether it was the RNC or
JFC that would send us statements with information that, you know, the building or the
JFC or the campaign we're talking about. And we kind of trained them to use that
information to craft the e-mails and that was kind of the process to start.
Q
Is it fair to say that one of the goals with writing copy in the role you were in
reviewing copy, was to capture the voice of the surrogate?
A
Yeah. When we write for a surrogate, we definitely want to capture their
voice in the messaging that they're sending out at that time.
Q
So tell me how that worked for President Trump?
A
What do you mean by that?
Q
When, if you were, when you were trying to capture President Trump's
voice, give us insight into again the sources you looked at and what that voice in your
estimation was, sounded like, looked like on paper?
A
So, we would grab from his Twitter, would be one place I'd grab a lot to
capture his voice. From various speeches that he had sometimes we would get, kind of,
the transcribed of whatever that speech was to incorporate those into our messaging. As
well as any statements that he put out.
So, those were kind of the main sources. There are probably others. He spoke a lot
during that time. And capturing that tone I think he obviously has a very aggressive
excitable tone, and we would try to incorporate that in our messaging as well.
Q
So, is it fair to say that when a recipient received an e-mail labeled from
President Trump you wanted it to sound like his voice?
A
We wanted to capture his voice and, you know, make it seem like obviously
it was coming directly from President Trump.
Q
Now with regard to surrogates, When you sent a surrogate e-mail did that
require approval from the surrogate?
A
Most of the time it required approval from the surrogate or the surrogate's
team. There are different processes for different surrogates but some form of approval
from that team or that individual. And after that approval it would still go through our
normal approval process beyond that.
Q
Do you recall the process for Kimberly Guilfoyle?
A
I don't remember who on her team or if she was involved in the approval
process. I know that we would send it to somebody on their team and they would send it
back.
Q
When you say their team, do you mean her team?
A
Kimberly's team.
Q
Okay. And could you recall who those people were or that person was?
A
I don't recall, No.
Q
Now I just want to -- on the technical way the assignment process worked.
Tell us a bit about how you gave assignments to Hannah and how she then provided copy
back to you.
A
So, it was kind of a mix. I would give her directives to do certain e-mails but
then sometimes her own people on the team were kind of bringing ideas up and sending
them to me. It didn't all come directly from me.
But in the instance where I was sending her something, I'd see something on
Twitter or the news or maybe something that a surrogate said that was timely,
newsworthy I would send that to her and her and the team would kind of take it from
there and craft it into a fundraising e-mail.
Q
How would you know what to talk about in fundraising e-mails, the topics
that are relevant or otherwise worthy of focus in an e-mail or text message?
A
I think a lot of it is really what President Trump is saying, in general and over
the years. But that has been something that is successful in fund raising. And to be honest
I can always know if it's going to work.
I try to go off of past experience and then kind of a good gauge is just what are the
headlines in the news? What are people talking about? That's what people want to hear
about. It's kind of an assumption and then we go from there.
We may be covering this in a moment, but I just want to clarify one
thing. A moment ago, you said that part of why you use President Trump's messaging was
because it was successful in fundraising. Was it also easier to get approvals if the
President said it in terms of well it's a message out there that you could use? Did that
impact the approval process at that time?
Mr. Boedigheimer.
No. From our perspective we could use President Trump's
language and then once we sent it through the approval chain, whether it was easy or not
for them to approve it then I think that would be up for them to determine. But it was
kind of our assumption that if President saying it was something that we would want to
replicate in e-mail.
Okay. Thank you.
Mr. Boedigheimer.
BY
Q
Yeah.
So, Austin, I understand that in 2020, tell me if this is correct, that with Covid
and the lack of in person fundraising that on line fundraising took and even more
prominent role in Presidential politics. Is, was that your experience?
A
I think online fund raising and digital in general, you know, took a huge raise.
Everybody stuck at home and everything.
Q
Yeah. So, tell us a bit about who was, you're overseeing the e-mail and text
fundraising teams for the campaign which appears to be kind of the heart of fundraising
for the Presidential election. Tell us about who is overseeing your work -- Hannah giving
you copy, you're setting it up, it's all coming in, who's checking in with you to make sure
you're doing it correctly, this is working, giving you feedback?
A
You know, like I said earlier, Kevin was my direct report and also Gary Colby,
I'm kind of reporting to in some fashion as well. You know mostly ideas, like I said, kind of
came from the bottom up. They weren't really directing. They were kind of looking more
at the numbers. Maybe they have an idea occasionally.
But then beyond that who is like reviewing the work would be the approval chain
reviewing the work, making sure the, it covers all the things that they need it to cover. As
far as, like, each individual piece of copy, other than the approval chain it's not something
that Gary or Kevin would have reviewed everything.
Q
Was there anyone else besides Gary or Kevin you were having meetings with
about the success of this fundraising efforts. And by that, I mean, I understand that
he's -- Kevin's your direct report. You were direct report to him. But I'm really thinking like
who's talking to Austin about here are the fund raising projections.
Here's how much has come in. Here's what's working. Who are you giving
feedback about what your team is doing on a day-to-day basis? And what's that look like?
Are we talking weekly meetings? Reports that you produced. Give us some insight there.
A
There'd be from the reporting side, we had the reporting team that handled
that. And Chris Georgia who worked at FP1 Strategies. He was kind of in charge of the
reporting. So, I don't know that we had like a weekly cadence or meeting like that. But
kind of the senior digital team would meet about the numbers relatively regularly.
So, that would have included Kevin and Gary, which we spoke about, and also
Chris Georgia. Let's see if there's anyone else here. Daria, can't remember, Dena bra [ph]
that's her last name, and Jess Woody [ph] and Jen Harrington [ph]. I think that was all
that, kind of, that group was.
And so, we would regularly talk about the fundraising. You know, what our
projections were for the month. That's kind of where we'd have that. I'd also talk with my
team about how much money we raised, and they had access to the reports as well. So, it
was pretty open for everyone to see.
Q
Did you ever have input that came directly or indirectly from the Trump
A
Me personally, I did not have any input. I don't know if others did.
Q
I'm asking you indirectly, meaning if someone expressed thoughts that you
family?
understood to be from a member of the Trump family.
A
Not that I can think of right now.
Q
What about Sean Doleman CFO?
A
What about him?
Q
Did he, did you have conversations, otherwise did he weigh in on your
efforts with digital fundraising?
A
Not that I can remember. The only thing that Sean and I would ever really
talk about would be his, it would be about like the merchandise that we were selling.
Q
Talking about it to what degree?
A
Mostly he was curios how much products cost and how much we were
spending on them.
Q
What about Bill Stepien and Justin Clark? Bill Stepien, any, in 2020 did you
have any interaction with or received any messaging from directly or indirectly?
A
Not that I can remember specific any fundraising directives. Bill stepped in,
spoke to the whole campaign many times. But other than that, I didn't have interactions
with him.
Q
What about Justin Clark?
A
Same thing there. He would speak sometimes during like an all campaign but
not something we talked about.
Q
In 2020 did you have any meetings where the broad messaging and
fundraising e-mails was discussed and you were given directives about anything about
messaging? Tell me how that worked whether any top-down directives you got.
A
I don't really remember any top-down directives. You know, as I kind of
explained earlier the process was more of seeking out the information that we were
getting and then sending that up. So, the ideas were coming from multiple people. But
the comm statements and Twitter's primarily where we got that. It wasn't constantly
someone telling you exactly what to do.
Q
Did you get any feedback that you were, in 2020, that you were
underperforming throughout the fund raising?
A
From who?
Q
From anyone.
A
From anyone?
Q
I'm trying to get a sense of your 2020 when you guys basically crushed it and
that just it went well. Or did you ever get any feedback that projections weren't met, or
goals weren't met and to take any action to correct that.
A
I'm sure there were days where we underperformed. We had access to the
reports. As far as how much money we were raising that's something I spoke to with Gary
and Kevin quite a bit. So, if there was any feedback like that it would have came from
them or I would have noticed myself that we were short of a goal.
Q
So, when you're short of a goal what did you respond with?
A
Typically our response is to try to make an adjustment, see why we were
short of the goal or, you know, maybe test different messages see what performs the
best and kind of go from there.
Q
So, let's get a little more specific. When you want to find out how or why you
were short of a goal, tell us with more specific detail. What do you do? Do you go back,
was is e-mail by e-mail you see what, you kind of figure out what went wrong with the
e-mail? When you say you test the messages, what does that mean? Give us a little more
insight.
A
Yeah. There's obviously a lot of things that we look into, and I wouldn't look
into all of them myself. But we could look at the e-mail-by-e-mail performance. We could
look at performance by channel, meaning, like how much did e-mail raise yesterday
compared to what it normally does.
How much did text message raise, you know, compared to what it normally does.
Look at messaging like see ones that didn't work, didn't raise that much money. Other
thing we could look for is kind of flaws in the system. Maybe in, you know, the correct
audience wasn't hit, or any type of inconsistencies or irregularities is kind of what mostly
people look for.
Q
you know that?
A
If you want to see that something was wrong or right messaging, how would
I don't know, I guess wrong or right, I don't know if that's the best term but
like if it was succeeding or not.
Q
Yeah. In fact, that we're not, how would you determine that?
A
I don't remember exactly what they were but we kind of had essentially
benchmarks of how much we expected or what kind of our average e-mail would be. So,
if it was under that it was obviously lower performing. If it was above that it was higher
performing.
And how would you know what was wrong with the messaging or right with
Q
the messaging?
A
I don't think we would know specifically what it was. It would be something
that we would have to test and kind of see how it impacts.
Q
And would you test different messaging?
A
We would test message, yeah, we would test different messaging.
Q
So, give us an example of messaging you would test.
A
I don't think I have a specific example but we could grab like one thing from
messaging from President Trump and then grab a different one that he had sent out a
different time and run those against each other and see which performed better.
Q
So, as an example something as specific as radical left versus leftist. Is that
an example or is that too specific?
A
I think that's pretty specific for a test. I don't know if anybody ran that. A lot
of people run tests on the team just in general. Usually, we look for like broader tests
where there's, you know, enough variance.
Q
So, what's an example? Is it like social security versus immigration or are you
talking about difference in tone? I'm trying to get insight into what you can know and
what you can't know.
Mr. Steggerda.
Mr. Boedigheimer.
Do you remember any specific examples?
Yeah. I don't think I can remember any specific examples.
But, I mean, testing is kind of, you can test any of those things. But we tested hundreds
and hundreds of tests. So, I can't remember all of them.
BY
Q
Did you test post-election?
A
I don't remember specifically if we did. It's very possible that we did.
Q
Is it fair to say that it's, the point of testing is to make sure you're being as
effective in fundraising as you can?
Yeah. I think the goal of testing is, yeah, see which contents is going to
A
perform better.
Q
So, it wouldn't surprise you if you tested post-election?
A
It wouldn't surprise me. I just don't remember specifically if we did.
Reporter.
BY
Yes. Talk a bit about Salesforce. How did you use the Salesforce platform in
Q
your work in 2020?
A
function.
Q
Before we go on can I have everyone just slow down a bit please?
Primarily in my work it was used to send out e-mails was its primary
And what was the, it's call the Performance Metrics Component of
Salesforce. Tell us how you used that.
A
You mean for fund raising e-mails or.
Q
So, our understanding is that the RNC had an account with Salesforce that
included get around the reports for example. And that you could look and see open rates,
quick rates, deliverability and all things of that nature. Does that sound all accurate?
A
Yeah. We could view that and a Datarama portion of it.
Q
And would you view that in order to determine basically how an e-mail
performed?
A
Yeah, that's where we would go to view the results.
Q
Okay. And you would look at those results and based on that you'd make
changes with your future e-mail campaigns. Is that fair?
A
Sometimes that's what we would do. Other times it would just be again
grabbing what the messaging of the day was regardless of performance.
Q
Is it fair to say that when you see messaging repeated numerous times with
the campaign from TMAGAC that we can infer that it's because that messaging was
determined to be effective?
A
Yeah. I think without knowing the exact whatever the e-mails are but if you
were sending it repeatedly it's the understanding that it's doing well so you want to keep
sending e-mails like that.
Q
And when sometimes we've seen e-mails that look pretty much identical.
Looks like the exact same e-mail was sent at one point and then a couple of weeks later
it's sent again, or a week later. Is it fair to say that that would happen because the e-mail
was deemed to be affective fundraising?
